member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Automata.PushdownAutomaton`1
member.summary:
A simple Pushdown Automaton with states as objects.
If your state classes have an empty constructor, the state machine can register the states automatically when needed (using and ). If not you should register the states yourself using or and use the regular.
The machine will automatically pool the states so you don't have to worry about it.
Whether or popping the last state is valid is up to your design.
member.typeparam: The type of the context.

member.name: P:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Automata.PushdownAutomaton`1.Context
member.summary: A shared context which all states have access to.

member.summary: The active state.

member.name: M:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Automata.PushdownAutomaton`1.#ctor(`0)
member.summary:
Creates a new PushdownAutomaton.
You should use to register which state types that can be used with the machine.
member.param: Data shared among states

member.summary: Call this every time the machine should update. Eg. every frame.

member.summary:

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Automata.FiniteStateMachine`1
member.summary:
A simple Finite State Machine with states as objects inspired by Prime31's excellent StateKit.
If your state classes have an empty constructor, the state machine can create the states automatically when needed (using ). If not you should create the state instance yourself and register the state in the machine.
Whether or not a null state is valid is up to your design.
member.typeparam: The type of the context.

member.summary: The previously active state.

member.name: M:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Automata.FiniteStateMachine`1.#ctor(`0)
member.summary:
Creates a new Finite State Machine.
If you need control over how the states are created, you can register them manually using . If not, then you can freely use which will create the states using their default constructor.
member.param: A shared context for the states.

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Events.Event
member.summary:
A simple event handler that uses interfaces instead of delegates to avoid the garbage generated by them.
This is the parameterless version. See if you need to send data with the event.
Listeners are required to implement the interface.
Events are differentiated by an integer. You are expected to create constants to define your events and make them unique.

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Events.GlobalEvents
member.summary:
A manager of events that do not belong to any specific object but instead can be listened to by anyone and invoked by anyone.
Useful for GameLoaded, MatchEnded and similar events.
This uses which in turn uses interface instead of delegates in order to avoid the often short-lived memory they allocate.
This version is for parameterless events. See if you need to send data with the events.
Events are differentiated by an integer. You are expected to create constants to define your events.

A relay for Unity update events. Here's why you might want to use this: https://blogs.unity3d.com/2015/12/23/1k-update-calls/ In short; avoid overhead of Native C++ --> Managed C# calls.
Also useful for non-MonoBehaviours that needs to be part of the update loop as well.
Events your can subscribe to:

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Gravity.GravitationalSystem
member.summary:
A gravitational system to allow for a more flexible gravity instead of just a constant directional gravity.
Useful for planets, black holes, magnets etc.
Rigidbodies that should be affected should have the component (or if using 2d physics).
Add gravitational forces by implementing the interface and registering it in the system. See for a simple example implementation.
You might want to set Unity's gravity to (0,0,0).

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Utils.BetterTime
member.summary:
A simple wrapper for Unity's that caches values to avoid the marshal overhead of each call.
The performance benefit is very small, but completely free.
Only readonly properties (except for ) are cached, but everything is wrapped anyway so you don't have to use multiple time classes.
Since this is just a wrapper just refer to Unity's documentation about what each property does.

member.name: T:Archon.SwissArmyLib.Utils.ServiceLocator
member.summary:
A (somewhat) simple implementation of the service locator pattern. The ServiceLocator knows about MonoBehaviours and how to work with them. Creating scene-specific resolvers that only live as long as their respective scene is also supported.
Please note that when you load a new scene, the MonoBehaviours in that scene will have their Awake() method called before their scene becomes the active one. This means you can't rely on SceneManager.GetActiveScene() to return the scene they're in, so you might want to use GameObject.scene to specify which scene to register the resolver for.

member.summary: Locates and returns a transient object or singleton of the specified type. Searches for a global object first, if nothing is found and is true then it searches for a scene specific resolver. Make sure the type is registered first.
member.typeparam: The type to locate an implementation for.
member.param: Whether to search for a scene specific resolver if a global one isn't found.
member.returns: The transient object or singleton that is mapped to the specified type. If nothing is registered for the default value for the type is returned.
